items.title: Pierre Polievre wants a Churchill base, but experts debate northern Manitoba town's military capacity
items.summary_auto: Party leader Pierre Poilievre says a Conservative government would build a base in Churchill to strengthen Canada's defence systems — but experts argue the northern Manitoba town presents challenges as a military location.

items.title: Evacuation orders remain in Badger, N.L., water levels 'still high'
items.summary_auto: The mayor of Badger says he’s “cautiously optimistic” after seeing a drop in water levels – but river water is still high and evacuation orders remain in place.

items.title: On home turf, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith jabs familiar foes to warm reception
items.summary_auto: Alberta Premier Danielle Smith flexed her star power amongst Conservative Party faithful on Saturday, advocating for popular conservative policies while not directly addressing the separatist issue that has made headlines this week.

items.title: Liberals announce Danielle Martin will be their candidate for University-Rosedale byelection
items.summary_auto: The Liberal Party announced Saturday afternoon that family physician Dr. Danielle Martin will be their candidate for the upcoming federal byelection in University-Rosedale, the downtown Toronto riding Chrystia Freeland held until she stepped down earlier this month.

items.title: Judge orders U.S. to free 5-year-old boy, father detained by ICE in Minnesota
items.summary_auto: Images of Liam Conejo Ramos wearing a bunny hat and Spiderman backpack while surrounded by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers sparked even more outcry about the Trump administration's immigration crackdown in Minnesota.

items.title: North Atlantic right whale found dead after weeks of entanglement
items.summary_auto: A North Atlantic right whale named Division was found dead in U.S. waters this week, entangled in fishing gear. It's the first entanglement death of 2026, according to the Canadian Whale Institute.

items.title: What to know about the Strait of Hormuz as Iran-U.S. tensions rise
items.summary_auto: The Strait of Hormuz, the narrow mouth of the Persian Gulf, again has become a focus of tensions as Iran prepares to launch a military drill that could see fire into a lane crucial for global shipping.

items.title: Race to export beyond U.S. picks up as tariff squeeze grips Canada
Helsinki wants Pamela Anderson to connect with her Finnish roots. So, it put a billboard up near her B.C. home
items.summary_auto: The European city of Helsinki is, in the least subtle way possible, encouraging Pamela Anderson to explore her Finnish heritage, going so far as offering to help her change her name.

items.title: Israeli strikes kill at least 30 Palestinians, as Gaza ceasefire inches forward
items.summary_auto: Hospitals in Gaza said Israeli strikes killed at least 30 Palestinians on Saturday, one of the highest tolls since the October ceasefire aimed at stopping the fighting.

items.title: Proposed tundra swan hunting season on Prairies prompts concern from hunter
items.summary_auto: The federal government is considering a proposal to establish a new hunting season for tundra swans in Alberta, Manitoba and Saskatchewan — a move that one hunter says could endanger the trumpeter swan, a similar-looking, sensitive species.

items.title: From Sask.'s frozen lakes to Olympic stage, here's a Canadian mogul skier's road to Milano-Cortina
items.summary_auto: Saskatoon’s Maïa Schwinghammer is days away from competing at the Olympics in Milan

items.title: Lake Erie has more ice in late January than any winter in the past 23 years
items.summary_auto: Great Lakes scientist Mike McKay says he was caught off guard by how much ice coverage was added so quickly. He estimates roughly 20,000 square kilometres of ice was gained over a six-day stretch in January.

items.title: A Mexican influencer is kidnapped on camera, a sign that social media is another battlefront in cartel wars
items.summary_auto: Nicole Pardo Molina’s kidnapping added to a grim tally that’s been slowly growing over the past five years across Mexico, which has seen at least  21 social media influencers kidnapped or killed.

items.title: Was Mark Carney's Davos speech a mistake if it upset Trump?
items.summary_auto: It's not unreasonable to think about how any action by a Canadian government might impact relations with Canada's largest trading partner. At the same time, allowing the American president's potential for anger to dictate the behaviour of Canadian leaders risks ceding a great amount of power.

items.title: The subject of Lyme disease is littered with misinformation. Celebrities are part of the problem, experts say
items.summary_auto: Chronic Lyme disease isn't recognized by conventional medicine. It's a controversial term used by some alternative practitioners to describe pain, fatigue and neurological symptoms they attribute to a persistent Lyme infection. Some Lyme experts say it’s fuelling a dubious industry and say celebrity cases are part of the problem.

items.title: The Golden Dome is where Canada's F-35 debate and Trump's Greenland threat meet
items.summary_auto: Two of the loudest and most important defence policy issues facing Canada have a common — often unrealized — thread, say experts. Both the F-35 and the U.S. threats to annex Greenland are connected over the Trump administration's plan to build its Golden Dome missile defence system.

items.title: Fearing ICE, some students in Minneapolis retreat to virtual learning
items.summary_auto: In some classrooms in the Twin Cities, more than half of the desks sit empty. The children of immigrants are increasingly absent from school, sports teams and even front yards, fearful that immigration and customs agents will detain them, or their parents, because of the colour of their skin.

items.title: Xi Jinping’s purge of China's top general spells uncertainty for world’s largest military
items.summary_auto: China's highest-ranked military general’s purge leaves President Xi Jinping almost alone at the helm of the military. Despite no one knowing for sure what led to this latest crackdown, there's a lot of speculation about what it means for the biggest army in the world.

items.title: What's the point of going back to the moon?
items.summary_auto: Artemis II is set to blast off to the moon in early February with four astronauts, including the Canadian Space Agency's Jeremy Hansen. But we've already been to the moon, so why are we going back? Do we get any benefits here on Earth?

items.title: Once seen as a crisis, the RCMP's recruitment numbers are starting to turn around
items.summary_auto: The RCMP's ability to recruit new Mounties was, not all that long ago, seen as a crisis. But new numbers suggest the national police force is starting to turn that around.

items.title: We’ve already been to the moon, so why are we going again?
items.summary_auto: Artemis II is set to blast off to the moon in early February with four astronauts, including the Canadian Space Agency's Jeremy Hansen. But we've already been to the moon, so why are we going back? Do we get any benefits here on Earth?
